comments: Only recommended if it is a requirement.
um. it's interesting! but the last part of the course kind of ruined all the linear algebra for me.
The material in the class is interesting and very useful, but the instruction is poor
If you have to take linear algebra, this is the course.

This class demands much and gives little (or perhaps no) reward in return. The material taught in the course is largely inapplicable to real problems and is only useful as a foundation for higher level mathematics. Unless you are seriously considering majoring in mathematics, do not take this course. If you want your math to have any real purpose (e.g., for practical use in the sciences), this is NOT the course for you. Also, if you enjoy a thorough understanding of the principles you learn, rather than a cursory overview of them as the professor continuously tries to catch up to the pace he has established but been unable to maintain with the homework assignments, take a different course.
Provides good intro to the topic, but there is a fair amount of work, take if you're interested or will take something else that has this as a prereq
Recommend it to someone only if they have to fulfill a requirement.
I would recommend it only to students who needed to take the class or were interested in the subject.
Unless you need to take it, don't - you could probably learn just as much by finding a good textbook and reading it on your own.

AWESOME!

I learned a lot and had a lot of fun at the same time.
The class material is very interest and good to learn. But they are taught very poorly. You have to learn the material on your own.
The material is useful, but dull.
I recommend that students only take this class if it is needed for a concentration requirement. The class is poorly taught and ruins an interesting topic.
Take it if you need it for a requirement, otherwise take a more interesting math course.

Do not take this course unless you absolutely have to.  If you need linear algebra for a concentration requirement, perhaps applied math would be better.  This class does not achieve a balance between theory and application.  You will understand neither.
I would only recommend this course to those who need to fulfill a concentration requirement. The course is not very well organized and by itself is not very useful.
A student's experience in Math 21b will depend greatly on his/her TF.
no one takes it unless it is required so it doesn't really matter what i recommend
I don't think it's necessarily well taught, but it is a good class for learning the basics of linear algebra.

This is a very challenging class if math is not your strong suit or this class is just being used to fulfill requirements. I would only suggest taking this class if you are interested in matrices and can motivate yourself to put work into understanding the more abstract applications and topics behind matrices and linear algebra. Overall, I learned a good amount in this course, but it was still a big struggle to get through it.
Although it is not taught as well as 21a, it is an important course to take for people who want a strong foundation in mathematics.
Oliver Knill is an amazing preceptor.
it is not a very interesting class. i would not take it as an elective
boring and painful, but required
The course head is very effective - make use of his office hours!
Take the class only if you really like math or if you need to take this course as a requirement for higher level courses in other disciplines.
Only take this class if it is required

You should be committed to working psets and learning the material on your own. It's likely you'll have a love/hate relationship with the class - the love because you should take this class only if you like math and the hate because of the work, the weird exams and some of the unclear examples.
Good last math class to take
Just cuz you loved 21a doesn't mean you will love 21b. They are really quite different.
GET OUT OF YOUR SECTION IF YOUR TF IS BAD!!!! IT IS THE ONLY WAY YOU WILL SUCCEED!!!
Be prepared to work for seemingly no reason.

The topics in this course are good to know, and I know a lot of people who really like the class, but it is different than a lot of math courses and if you don't have previous knowledge of linear algebra, then there are a lot of conventions you have to learn before getting into the math.
Keep your fingers crossed for a good TF.

This is a good class if you like memorizing algorithms and applying them to different situations. Usually the people who take 21b like math a lot more than the people who take 21a, so the curve on the tests is higher, but the atmosphere in class is more positive. If you want to do well on the tests, practice the difficult algorithms until you can do them really quickly.
Very hard. Definitely you must study for multiple days before each exam.
The material taught in this course is very interesting and can be applied to so many different things from different disciplines in the sciences.
Linear algebra is really interesting. It is different from a math course and makes you think in a different perspective... all in all, very good training for the mind.
You will learn linear algebra with no frills attached. If thats what you want its a great course.
It's challenging, but worthwhile provided you have a good TF.
Don't take it unless it is required--it's a lot of work.

It makes no sense for anyone to take as an elective, but as a requirement it teaches you a lot and is very, very well-organized. You can teach yourself out of the book if you have to, but for me going to lecture and hearing the material made a big difference.
Interesting yet tough. Definitely learned a lot.
take 23 if you can

-while the course does provide a solid linear algebra background, it did not provide a thorough understanding of differential equations, especially of the pdes.
-the overall nature of the course is a bit rushed;
It's hard and really should not be taken with other demanding classes.
you should like math.

Like it or not, any student in a quantitative field should take a basic course in linear algebra and differential equations in college, and Math 21B is the standard. Some of the topics are very interesting and virtually all have applications in a number of fields, so it is a very useful course to take. Due to the way it is taught in sections with homework due every lecture, Math 21B is not exactly the most fun class, but it teaches you what you need to know at a high level and fulfills a standard prerequisite for many higher level courses.

Go to section.  It's easy to get overwhelmed if you don't stay on top of your work.  Also, if you have any commitments on Monday nights, do not take Tuesday-Thursday section times because you will have 2 homeworks due on Tuesday mornings.
If you think you might even have the faintest chance of liking math (and not just fulfilling a requirement) then don't take math 21a/b but math 23 or 101.
There is a significant amount of work to this class.  However, it provides a very complete look at linear algebra, including more theoretical topics as well as practical application.
Make sure you do the homework and read the book.
This is not an easy A, but with a moderate amount of studying, this will prove to be a nice course: do not start your problem set an hour before it's due.
Take 23 or 25 or 55. Math 21b is not worth your time if you actually want to learn math.
I don't enjoy math so I didn't like this class.

The work can be fairly difficult but if you work together with others on it in the math question center you get a good understanding of what you are doing and come away with a good experience.  The material is in my opinion more useful than multivariable calculus.
Only take this if you have an idea what it covers and are genuinely interested.

For those not in math, physics, or engineering, Math 21a and 21b are a great way to finish up your math education and learn about all the more interesting and theoretical possibilities in higher-level math. They might also spark an interest in a math concentration, although they didn't for me (not because 21a and b were boring, just because other classes were more interesting personally).
Do your homework. Catch-up before exams is not fun.
If you get a bad TF go to another section.
section is useless
Take it if you must. But take 19 if you can.
A lot of work on a weekly basis

- try to get Judson as course head
- Oliver's hilarious & brilliant, but a little too fast
The class is hard and you probably will never use what you learn after the first week again in your life.
difficult but do-able if you have a good TF
Its very different from all previous math classes taken.
The structure/materials for the class aren't great, but the material is interesting and useful! Perhaps take it with a different professor than Knill, if another professor offers it.

The course is too stressful for what it's worth; the lessons are taught at a decent level at the beginning, but then begin to become unclear and insufficient as soon as the material gets tougher; what's more, most of the class seems to revolve around "learning it yourself" through homework, MQC, and asking questions at office hours or problem sections, rather than actually learning the material in class; midterms threw the learned material back at us at a much higher level; the course seemed to be littered with various applications that were not only confusing but did not substantially add to the understanding of the material
This would be the best class for science students to take.  The applications of linear algebra to the sciences are endless.  The non-theoretical approach may not appeal to mathematics concentrators.

This will be really tough and fairly rushed, especially towards the end with Fourier Series. Do not take this course unless you a) really love math or b) really, really need to take this course to satisfy a concentration requirement.
Not as hard as Math 21a.  Especially for those who had no previous experience in Multivariable calculus because in 21b, much less people have had previous exposure as with 21a.
Take it if you want to complete your math background.
If linear algebra isn't your thing, be prepared for a difficult semester.
The beginning of the course may seem easy, but continue to pay attention because material can begin to go over you head quickly if you are not prepared for it.

This is a much more practical math class than most.  Although you probably won't be using linear algebra in every day life, it applies to life much better than most math subjects (like multivariable calculus).
Reading the textbook is the most useful of anything you could do in this class.
it's a little difficult in the beginning because it's new, but then when the final comes around I think everything falls into place.

You need to learn the material on your own time. The homework is just obligatory; it doesn't help. There are a slew of other books that will help more than the Bretscher book. Linear Algebra is, however, very important to learn so it's useful to take this class to motivate you to learn the material properly.
If not interested in high level theory or proofs, this is a great course to take for linear algebra.
It's relatively light-load if you settle for a superficial understanding of the material.
Be wary of the lack of helpful instruction

Make sure that you study for the exams to do well on the exams. Doing well on Prof Knill's exams doesn't always mean understanding the material in a generally deep way. It does mean knowing several of the tricks that he likes because he thinks that they help make deep points about the material. Whether that works or not is not up for me to decide, but I do think that what it means for studying for the exams is pretty clear--PRACTICE TESTS.
It's a lot of work, but it's fun and interesting.
Who doesn't love Linear Algebra?
only if you need it, don't take it when Oliver Knill is course head
The exams are really, really, really, kick-you-in-the-face-and-laugh-at-you-while-you-writhe-in-pain-on-the-ground hard.

It is a good class in terms of the material. Exams are irrelevant sometimes and section is useless, so you have to work on your own. Don't underestimate it.. it catches up really fast, the end is difficult.
it's a good class, but if you don't have to take it for any requirements, it's probably not the most exciting thing in the world.
This class is very disjointed in the material it presents, and the sections are so different that if you happen to get the wrong TF, your whole semester is ruined.
good pace, great course head, interesting material

Oliver Knill is a good teacher, but the quality of the TFs is not that good, at least compared to in 21a.

The concepts in this course are pretty abstract, you can't visualize a lot of things like in 21a, so that might make learning harder.
Take it only if you need it or really like math. It's hard. You can't just memorize, you really have to understand ALL the principles and relationships otherwise you'll get behind fast.
Class provides a good basis for linear algebra, but be ready to spend lots and lots of time on homework assignments.

the first week was deceiving (solving systems of equations), the first few weeks were daunting (a whole new language... what are kernels and images??), but the process is rewarding, and the end results are sweet. the language of linear algebra is a beautiful one
also, ALL three TFs are exceptionally qualified. i had rehana, but also went to Daniel Kane's office hour a lot - a superb lad who knows how to cater the material to the level that you are at
Take it and work hard. Math 21 classes are a pain with their 3 problem sets but use them as an opportunity to learn the material, not just get it over with.
A course with interesting math without overwhelming difficulty.
Very demanding course conceptually.

If you need to take Linear Algebra, you don't really have another choice... I suppose one could take Math 23, but particularly for economics majors the application of the material is much more useful than the proofs.
Great class, but I must say that this is partly due to my TF, Rehana. In previous math classes, I wasn't so fortunate.
Challenging class, but good material and instructors
Linear algebra is an incredibly useful set of math to know that is also very frustrating to learn.  Set your expectations high for a challenge and set aside a ton of time for homework.
It's a require class, but one I would not recommend if it was not required.
Take Math21b! The topics covered are very interesting!!
Easier than 21a in that there was less to learn (and psets were easier).  Harder than 21a if you need proof for every little thing because you won't get it.

If you're taking it as an elective, be aware that it's very easy to fall behind especially if you don't keep up with the homework. It's a time commitment, but very useful if you're taking science classes that use differential equations.
If you're interested in linear algebra, but do not want an extremely intense, math concentrator-like course this would be a pretty decent fit.
relaxing math class
If you want to learn linear algebra, this is the way to do it!
The homework sucks.
Demanding and time consuming.

The material is very difficult and the problems sets are long... it will definitely be a very work heavy class. I think a lot of the experience depends on who's the course head. Rehana Patel did a very good job, but I don't know who might course head in other years.
Don't take it for fun, but if you have to take it for your concentration, it's really nothing to worry about / be sad about.
If you take this course, be prepared to teach yourself the material.
It is a very interesting math class that actually gives the students skills. Take it if you are at all interested in computing, modelling etc.

Do not be discouraged to take this class after Math 21a. It is much more fun, interesting, and understandable. You will put a lot of work in, but it is not an impossible course if you keep with with your work.
The material covered is no particularly interesting, but it provides you with an extremely useful  mathematical language and skills
I mean it's math...only take it if you have to.

This is a course in linear algebra.  If you're looking to work with matrices and all their applications, this is the class.  If you are interested in differential equations only, look for another class.
useful material, lot of work if you want to do well, cant slack off

Its hard, but you can do well. You can get help, the MQC is great and there is always a way to improve- thats why this class is great as opposed to other harvard courss. it may not be the BEST taught class or the most amazing structure, but you learn a lot and its really useful. i would definitely take it if you're willing to work hard.

Seriously, Bretscher's book sucks. I don't know why we keep using it year after year. It's absolutely incomprehensible, and there are so many other better linear algebra books. I think the usage of Bretscher's book is a clear example of nepotism. 

Just read the Amazon.com reviews, they're so clear that this is one of the worst linear algebra books ever written:

http://www.amazon.com/Linear-Algebra-Applications-Otto-Bretscher/product-reviews/0136009263/ref=dp_top_cm_cr_acr_txt?ie=UTF8&showViewpoints=1
It's a tough class.
This class revived my love of math in the wake of multi-variable calculus.  It still has three problem sets a week, but that is the only way it is like Math 21a.

This is so much more useful that Math 21a. You will actually see that linear algebra is referenced in a number of other classes, whereas multivariable calc can be completely forgotten with relatively few repurcussions. If you are planning on taking any classes that are more mathy (e.g. advanced economics, statistics, etc.), you should def take this early on.

If you'd like to learn linear algebra and have a natural aptitude for math, take this course but be prepared to put a lot of work into it. Also be prepared to spend a lot of time learning obscure examples, which might make it difficult to focus on mastering the fundamental concepts and general problem types that you should know if you are planning to apply linear algebra in other fields.
Only take this course if you need it for a concentration requirement.
Don't take this class unless you have to.
Be prepared to spend a lot of time on problem sets. Use the MQC - it's very helpful.
It's really hard, so if you are taking it because you absolutely love math, then great! But if not...you should really think about how much time and effort you want to invest into this.

The class is demanding, especially because problem sets are due at every section. However, the course can be fun and the pain of the frequent homework can be alleviated if you attend problem sessions and office hours.
Keep up with the homework and readings, and you'll be fine. It takes a lot of time though...
Class is very well structured, MQC (math question center, open every night Monday - Friday) is super helpful, but material is hard, making problem sets and exams a struggle.
Get a study group, or at least a friend with whom to work together on psets

This class is pretty difficult and pretty abstract as well. Be prepared to think and problem solve a lot. It will really teach you some good critical thinking skills but the material doesn't necessarily come naturally to everybody so be prepared to work hard. John and Prince were great resources and the course is very well organized.
Best of luck.
This is a solid course that does what it sets out to do. You learn a lot of material, although at times is feels very theoretical. If you do not like a lot of theory, consider taking AM21b.
Cool and useful, more fun than Math 21a. John Hall was a great and caring teacher
I would recommend this class to people who have the time to devote to this course and are excited about the material.
This class is actually very interesting, albeit a bit confusing at times. The only part I would say I didn't enjoy is that it's very computation-heavy, but it's necessary to learn.

The math 21 sequence has been one of the best classes I've taken at Harvard.  The staff is passionate and accessible. You learn beautiful, interesting, relevant material, and they provide the resources for you to do it.  Sure, most people are taking this class as a requirement or prerequisite, but at the end of the day: 1. you need to know this stuff, and 2. you actually learned a ton in this class. The only people who complain about this class are people who wouldn't like the material any way it was presented.

I didn't find the course as satisfying as 21a, because the topics from day to day felt disjoint. It's not until the end that things begin to all connect, which is rewarding, but it's very easy to feel lost along the way. Especially while you're doing true/false questions.
do the worksheets and readings on the website, they help a lot more than what is taught in section
It's a great introduction to linear algebra, but does not focus as much (or teach as well) the portion on differential equations.

This course is largely dependent on your TF, and it was a nightmare for me personally. If you're a fan of computation, this may not be the course for you. It's based on a lot of terminology that may be difficult to visualize, but with resources like MQC, you can do well in the class. It was a complete snooze fest for me though, and that definitely affected my performance. Only take this class if you need it for a concentration requirement.

Shockingly well taught, take it instead of applied! The worst part about this course is that the material is interesting and you'll want to know why it's true, but this class really isn't about the "why"
21B has great application in many upper level courses. So I'd highly recommend that you take it.
dont take it

It's a lot of work (3 problem sets per week can take up a lot of time) but if you pay attention in class and go along with the worksheets they give you then it shouldn't be too difficult. Take the practice tests before the midterm and final and you should be alright.

If you do not know any linear algebra, you should take this course as it is a great introduction to the material and will give you a good foothold for other math or applied math courses at Harvard.  If you are familiar with some topics of linear algebra, you should skip this and go into AM 106 or AM 120.

I'm a mechanical engineer and I took this course because I started in 1b, so I was offset by a semester and could never take the applied 21 classes. However, I have no regrets! John Hall taught this class really well, and I feel like I now have a much better understanding of matrices and differential equations. Though the class went into topics that were difficult to conceptualize, there was plenty of material that could be applied to real-world problems. Though having three PSets a week is a giant pain, you will leave the class with a wonderful work ethic and understanding of linear algebra. Don't miss out on this class!
If you are more of an applied person like myself I would recommend applied 21b over this class.
Keep in mind that there are three problem sets a week and each will probably take about 3-4 hours to finish.
The exams are fairly difficult and expect a mastery of the material. Also, the three PSets a week take a significant amount of time out of your week.
The p-sets are actually interesting!

You don't need to take 21b for most concentration requirements, so don't make the same mistake I did. That said, this is an excellent course for those who want to grasp basic linear algebra and ODE concepts, taught by a professor who knows how to give a straightforward lecture.
Lots of work but fun.

I really love this class. It kinda made me fall in love with math again. It's not that hard if you like math and are really engaged. I would definitely take it, even if you feel a little intimidated. There are lots of opportunities for help.

This course is absolutely terrible.  The teaching is done so poorly you'll wonder why you even bother going to section.  The abstract material is a focus of this class so if you plan on going into science or engineering this will be a waste.  The teaching staff has members that have clearly never taught before and should never teach again.

The problem sets absolutely suck but they got me to really learn the material.  Beginning of the class was really theoretical and difficult to follow but I learned a lot from it. Definitely recommend taking this class if you are willing to put in the work.
This math class is interesting and well-organized.  It seemed fairly well-taught in all sections this fall, but things might be different in the spring when there are more sections.

This was by far the worst course I have taken at Harvard. The subject material was not difficult, but it was presented in a terrible fashion which led to me having to teach it all to myself after section. The structure of the course was horrible and I truly regret not waiting to take Applied. Left a bad taste in my mouth for the math department.

John Hall is awesome! This class does a great job of teaching the material and you get the help that you need. The material is very intriguing and applicable in many fields. Definitely take it! Lots of work but worth it in my opinion. Sometimes I felt like I learned the material but would struggle a bit on psets and exams, but I really felt like it was worth it.

This is an extremely theoretical course; it is very hard to visualize what is happening with transformations and whatnot, which is very different than 21a. You will learn a lot from this class, but be prepared to work hard and have your brain hurt. Also you will learn very quickly that true or false questions are not good things. Not at all.
Solid standard course.
If you can take the Math 23 track it is much more worthwhile than Math 21.  Math 21b is a nice class but it does not teach you how to prove anything.
Linear algebra is a lot of logical reasoning--if you don't like matrices and derivatives/integrals, it's probably not the class for you.

This is one of the most useful and applicable math classes you will ever take - which seems strange since it is billed as being "more theoretical."  But really! You learn the actual calculus and geometry behind a lot of computer science functions and statistical analysis, and - though the homework is copious - it really makes you practice those techniques.

It's a requirement for some concentrations, so you likely have to take it. The course is incredibly well taught with lots of resources to help you, but 3 problem sets a week is brutal. It helps you to keep on top of your material, but on the other hand it consumes a lot of your time.

John Hall designed a fabulous course! I genuinely enjoyed attending sections and doing the psets. This was by far my favorite class of the semester. Some parts were certainly challenging, but they were challenging in the right way - they mentally stimulated me, and once I arrived at the correct answer, I wanted to explore more. Definitely take this class if you need to fulfill a math requirement. The psets won't be onerous; you'll be glad that you're doing 3 psets a week because they really set solid foundations for advanced work in math.

Math 21b is a very difficult course. I took applied math 21a and did not enjoy it. I thought it was a really difficult class, not interesting material, and I could not stand learning math in a huge lecture. So I decided to take regular math 21b. I do not regret this decision: having three psets a week forces you to stay on top of the material and a small section setting where you can ask questions and participate is really great for learning. Also, Jessica was an amazing TF. That being said, this class was the biggest source of stress of my Harvard career. I found that my entire semester was consumed by psets, and the exams were highly stressful as well. I walked out of the midterms feeling sad and incapable, despite hours upon hours of studying. What was really hard for me was that I actually really enjoyed the material and found it super interesting. But the structure and design of the class made me dislike the experience. Taking this class made me realize that math was not for me, but I would never have known that had I not taken it, so if you're unsure about whether or not to take this class, I would say take it, challenge yourself.

If you're actually interested in learning the material, take regular instead of applied. Three psets a week isn't as annoying as it sounds, and it really does help make learning the material less stressful. Some people complain of the possibility of getting stuck with a bad section leader; taking 21b in the fall may help reduce this possibility. The class itself is pretty fun; if you have prior experience with linear algebra and differential equations then the class will be much easier but you will still be able to learn a lot.
It's a lot more theory based than you would think and it's rather difficult. You have to stay on top of things 24/7 or you will get lost, and quickly.

Math 21b is just about one of the most useful classes that Harvard and the Math Department offers. It is not a challenging class yet you learn so much in it!! It is your first taste of pure mathematics with all the definitions yet you can see the applications so clearly. And you learn two things (Linear Algebra and Differential Equations) that you can begin using immediately in whichever field you are interested in: Economics, Statistics, Engineering, Computer Science, Linguistics, Finance, Biology, Chemistry, and so on!!!!! I LOVED THIS CLASS! TAKE IT!!
This is a tough course.  But it is really cool material and it is presented in a very organized way.  It is very fulfilling.  Definitely be prepared to work hard.  3 psets a week is not easy.
